physicalObject: wireless game controller with gray camouflage pattern
proxyLocation: upper middle-left of Snapshot 1, lying flat on the table
utilizationMethod: Grip only the right hand-grip prong of the controller as if it were a mug handle; slip your index and middle fingers around the underside of the prong while the thumb rests on the outer curve. The weight of the controller creates a modest torque similar to a full mug suspended from its handle, letting you perform the lifting and wrist-tilt gesture required for sipping.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate weight that feels substantial since it's full, as well as a rotational moment around their grip point
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will perform a precision-to-power hybrid grip: the index and middle finger slip through the 2 cm-diameter handle while the thumb pinches the outside, or the whole hand wraps around the handle in a relaxed fist. The hand lifts the mug in a forearm curl, followed by wrist supination to bring the rim to the lips. Fine wrist rotation (~30-50°) tips the vessel, letting virtual liquid flow; the mug’s center of mass, offset from the grip point, produces a noticeable torque that the user compensates for with thumb and little-finger counter-pressure. After a sip, the mug is returned through the reverse motion and may be set down with a gentle vertical translation. Haptically the mug responds as a moderately heavy object (as if full), resisting sudden starts/stops and creating slight rotational inertia about the handle axis; no deformation is felt because it is rigid. If a real proxy is supplied, a cylindrical rod or small loop matching the handle diameter delivers the essential outline, while the weight can be simulated by attaching modest mass to the rod.

physicalObject: black stainless steel Tesla water bottle
proxyLocation: upper right of Snapshot 1, standing upright
utilizationMethod: Pinch the neck of the bottle between thumb and index finger so that the bottle body hangs downward, emulating a mug whose center of mass is offset from the grip point. Lift and tip the hanging cylinder to simulate bringing liquid to the lips; the steel body supplies realistic weight and rotational inertia.

physicalObject: yellow snack bag with Japanese text
proxyLocation: bottom left of Snapshot 1, lying flat
utilizationMethod: Fold the top edge of the bag loosely and insert your index and middle fingers underneath the fold while the thumb pinches the front, mimicking a slim handle loop. Although light, the flexible rim still guides the same precision-to-power grip and wrist rotation pattern used when tilting a mug.

physicalObject: small yellow metal binder clip
proxyLocation: center of Snapshot 1, slightly right
utilizationMethod: Open the binder clip and slip your fingers through one silver wire loop while your thumb rests on the opposite loop. The two stiff wire arms are almost exactly 2 cm apart and rounded, giving a convincing mug-handle outline and providing small but noticeable torque from the attached clip body when you tilt.

utilizationMethod: Grip the rim between thumb and index finger while letting the cup body dangle downward. The thin rigid rim supplies a circular edge your fingers wrap around, and the dangling cup creates an off-center mass you can tip like a mug being poured.

physicalObject: green plush turtle shell cushion with white rim
proxyLocation: upper left of Snapshot 2, resting on the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Pinch a section of the firm white rim between thumb and fingers, using it as an oversized but rounded ‘handle’. Lift the cushion so its bulk hangs away from your hand, producing clear rotational inertia that you then counteract while performing the sip-and-tilt motion.

physicalObject: wireless game controller with gray camouflage pattern
proxyLocation: upper middle-left of the desk in snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Wrap your dominant hand around the left grip horn of the controller as though it were a short axe handle; let the right-side horn jut forward to represent the axe head. The slight battery weight in the body produces a mild forward pull during a swing, giving a scaled-down sense of head-heavy inertia while still requiring a fist-style grasp around a chunky, contoured surface.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users employ a firm power grip with the dominant hand wrapped fully around the lower portion of the cylindrical handle—thumb overlapping the index finger in a classic tool grasp. Some users will add a secondary support hand nearer the head for precise placement, then slide it down for full-force swings. Interaction involves wide shoulder-driven arcs or over-the-head chopping motions with rapid acceleration and abrupt deceleration on impact. Because the mass is head-heavy, the user senses the head pulling the swing forward and a momentary lag when changing direction, encouraging follow-through. Upon striking a target, a short sharp vibration and rebound force is expected as the virtual blade ‘bites’ then stops; the system may briefly lock the position to convey embedment. A suitable physical proxy is a weighted stick whose distal end is heavier to replicate the forward inertia.

physicalObject: black stainless steel Tesla water bottle
proxyLocation: upper right area of the desk in snapshot 1 (standing upright)
utilizationMethod: Grip the bottle low near its base so the capped end projects forward as the ‘blade’. If the bottle contains liquid it will feel markedly top-heavy, closely mimicking the axe’s head-heavy inertia; even empty, the thick steel cap provides a forward bias. The cylindrical body encourages a full fist power-grip identical to an axe handle.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users employ a firm power grip with the dominant hand wrapped fully around the lower portion of the cylindrical handle—thumb overlapping the index finger in a classic tool grasp. Some users will add a secondary support hand nearer the head for precise placement, then slide it down for full-force swings. Interaction involves wide shoulder-driven arcs or over-the-head chopping motions with rapid acceleration and abrupt deceleration on impact. Because the mass is head-heavy, the user senses the head pulling the swing forward and a momentary lag when changing direction, encouraging follow-through. Upon striking a target, a short sharp vibration and rebound force is expected as the virtual blade ‘bites’ then stops; the system may briefly lock the position to convey embedment. A suitable physical proxy is a weighted stick whose distal end is heavier to replicate the forward inertia.

physicalObject: black and silver telescopic selfie stick with phone holder clamp
proxyLocation: top center of the yellow table in snapshot 3
utilizationMethod: Keep the selfie stick collapsed and grip the foam-covered bottom section as the handle; the phone clamp and hinge assembly at the far end act as the axe head. The metal shaft provides length and the clamp’s weight makes the device distinctly head-heavy, delivering swing inertia and a realistic full-hand cylindrical grip identical to an actual axe.

utilizationMethod: Hold the box by one of its shorter ends so the bulk of the rectangular mass projects forward. The cardboard provides a solid, graspable volume; swinging it gives palpable momentum concentrated at the front, approximating the feeling of an axe’s weighted head during chopping gestures.

Wrist-driven chops make the heavy mass lag and then pull forward, providing a strong sense of head-heavy inertia even though the ‘handle’ is short.

physicalObject: wireless game controller with gray camouflage pattern
proxyLocation: upper middle-left of Snapshot 1, resting on the tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grasp one of the two grip horns as though it were the hammer handle; allow the bulkier central body to protrude forward to act as the hammer head. Swing downward so the heavier mid-section stops against the table, giving a modest but noticeable head-weighted feel and a flat plastic impact surface.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users grasp the handle in a classic hammer fist grip—thumb diagonal across the fingers, palm wrapped tightly. Primary motion is elbow-driven downward strikes or short horizontal taps, often with only one hand. The head’s concentrated mass produces a pendulum effect: the handle feels light until mid-swing, then the user must brake the head at impact. Contact with a surface yields a sudden stop followed by a small recoil vibration suggesting a solid hit. Because the striking face is broader than an axe, precision is less critical; users may rapidly repeat strikes, so the interaction alternates between quick lifts and jolting stops. A realistic proxy is a short dowel with a heavy block attached near the top to convey head-heavy inertia and a flat striking face.

physicalObject: black stainless steel Tesla water bottle
proxyLocation: upper right of Snapshot 1, standing upright on the tabletop
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle low, about one-third up from its base, so most of the mass and the metal cap sit above the hand and create a top-heavy sensation. Swing downward to tap the cap against a surface, mimicking the pendulum effect of a hammer head while the cylindrical body supplies a firm round grip.

physicalObject: wireless game controller with gray camouflage pattern
proxyLocation: lying on the table, upper middle-left of image 0
utilizationMethod: Wrap your fingers around the left-hand grip of the controller as though it were the short wooden handle of a sickle. The right-hand grip, jutting forward, gives a protruding mass that can stand in for the curved blade. Swing the controller in a pulling, semicircular motion so the weight of the opposite grip produces the feeling of forward-biased inertia during the harvesting stroke.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users curl their fingers around the short cylindrical handle in a power grip, wrist oriented so the curved blade points forward and inward toward the forearm. Interaction consists of sweeping semicircular pull-strokes: the elbow leads while the wrist pronates slightly, dragging the blade through virtual vegetation. Because the mass is distributed along the curved blade rather than at a single point, the user feels moderate forward-weighted inertia that encourages a fluid slicing motion rather than abrupt chops. When the blade encounters resistance, the system should simulate a brief tug and rapid cessation of motion, as though stalks are severed. Returning strokes are lighter, resetting for the next cut. A proxy can be a short handle with a light but slightly forward-weighted extension (e.g., a plastic arc) to evoke the balanced yet biased inertia.

physicalObject: black stainless steel Tesla water bottle
proxyLocation: standing upright, upper right of image 0
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle near its base as the sickle’s handle. Because most of the bottle’s weight is distributed farther from your hand, the long metal body supplies noticeable forward inertia that mimics a blade’s mass when you sweep the arm in an arcuate cutting motion.

proxyLocation: near bottom center of image 1
utilizationMethod: Grip the pen close to its cap end like a miniature tool handle, letting the longer ink barrel represent the blade extension. Though straight and light, the pen still provides a distinct forward section that can be swung in concise semicircular motions for practice of the wrist pronation used with a sickle.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users curl their fingers around the short cylindrical handle in a power grip, wrist oriented so the curved blade points forward and inward toward the forearm. Interaction consists of sweeping semicircular pull-strokes: the elbow leads while the wrist pronates slightly, dragging the blade through virtual vegetation. Because the mass is distributed along the curved blade rather than at a single point, the user feels moderate forward-weighted inertia that encourages a fluid slicing motion rather than abrupt chops. When the blade encounters resistance, the system should simulate a brief tug and rapid cessation of motion, as though stalks are severed. Returning strokes are lighter, resetting for the next cut. A proxy can be a short handle with a light but slightly forward-weighted extension (e.g., a plastic arc) to evoke the balanced yet biased inertia.

physicalObject: silver metal USB-C hub/adapter
proxyLocation: bottom right of image 1
utilizationMethod: Pinch the short USB-C plug between thumb and forefinger as the handle. The rectangular hub body then sticks forward, giving a modest front weight. Slice the hub through space in curved pulls; its aluminum heft, while small, adds perceptible inertia ahead of the grip similar to a short sickle blade.

physicalObject: black and silver telescopic selfie stick with phone holder clamp
proxyLocation: top center of image 2, lying horizontally
utilizationMethod: Grasp the padded handle of the selfie stick just as you would the sickle’s wooden grip. Keep the telescopic pole partly extended so the clamp end provides forward length and noticeable weight distribution. When you perform sweeping, inward pull strokes, the extended rod’s inertia approximates the balanced yet forward-weighted feel of a curved blade.

physicalObject: blue Pilot whiteboard eraser box
proxyLocation: bottom left of image 2
utilizationMethod: Hold one narrow end of the rectangular box like a stubby handle, letting the bulk of the box protrude forward. The box’s mass produces a clear moment arm so that rotating and pulling the wrist imparts a moderate inertial tug analogous to dragging a sickle blade through stalks.

physicalObject: silver cylindrical 500 g calibration weight
proxyLocation: bottom right of image 2
utilizationMethod: Grip the top knob of the weight between your fingers as a compact handle. The dense cylinder hanging below serves as a blade surrogate with pronounced forward-weighted inertia. Swinging the weight in tight semicircles gives a convincing tug and follow-through characteristic of cutting with a real sickle.
